moves.1. e4: Just to explain the time limit - it was 40 moves in 90 minutes each, after which 30 minutes is added the first time a player runs out of time. There is also a 30 second increment per move.
moves.1... c5: This time I couldn't really prepare as he sometimes plays 1. d4 or 1. c4.
moves.2. Nc3: He opts for a Closed Sicilian.
moves.3. g3: Quite a common way to handle this. I am already thinking a few minutes on my reply.
moves.5... e6: More common is d6, but this is perfectly playable.
moves.6... b6: 6... d6 planning a6 and b7-b5 is more normal, but this got him thinking!
moves.7. Nf3: He decides to open up the game.
moves.8. d4: And he does his central thrust. I was quite surprised here that in previous games in this position, black had simply castled. I am not sure why white can't just take twice on c5 in that case. I was also afraid of allowing d4-d5 so I took!
moves.9... a6: I was afraid of him playing Nd4-b5 threatening to go to d6.
moves.10... Nxc6: I have to take back this way. If I take with the queen he exchanges queens and then takes on b6.
moves.14. c4: trying to open up the centre.
moves.14... b5: I want to divert that c pawn.
moves.15... Nxe5: I play this, rather than allow him a strong passed pawn on c6 if I had played 15....b x a4 16. d x c6
moves.16. fxe5: And white, running low on time offered a draw which I immediately accepted. Many thanks for reading. Please leave a comment or two and rate the annotation on the star system, so I know how I am doing. Until next time dear reader!

players: Donald J Mason (2129) vs. Charles Higgie (1915)
